cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Drivers trapped behind a slow-moving vehicle often:
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle plenty of space.
questions.answerC: Are happy with the speed of travel.
questions.explanation: It is common for drivers to tailgate slow-moving vehicles that cannot keep up with the speed of surrounding traffic. If you are being tailgated, allow the other driver to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: It is important to inspect your tires before every drive. Rust around wheel nuts may indicate that they are loose.

questions.question: Mirrors should be checked:
questions.answerB: When changing lanes, but only when other vehicles are nearby.
questions.answerC: When changing lanes, but only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: Always check for traffic in your mirrors before changing lanes. Frequent mirror checks should be a part of your normal scanning routine.

questions.question: To apply for a CDL, an applicant must be at least:
questions.explanation: In California, you must be at least 18 years old to apply for a commercial driver license.

questions.question: If you’re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both side mirrors because it can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you can see how they do it.
questions.explanation: Before backing up, you should get out of your vehicle and look at your line of travel. Check your clearance to the sides and overhead.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Cargo should have one tie-down for every ____ of cargo.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: When stopping a manual transmission vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerB: Push the clutch out when the engine is close to idle.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when the engine is close to idle.
questions.explanation: When stopping, apply gradual pressure to the brake pedal and stop smoothly. If stopping a manual transmission vehicle, push the clutch in when the engine is close to idle.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced loads can lead to unsafe handling. It is important to properly distribute the weight of cargo when loading a vehicle.

questions.question: One way to prevent hydroplaning on wet road surfaces is to:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.explanation: When driving on a wet road surface, the risk of hydroplaning is increased if your tire pressure is too low or your tire tread is too worn. If you begin to hydroplane, release the accelerator and push in the clutch to slow down.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: If you must drive in reverse, using driver's side backing:
questions.answerC: Is only recommended if it is raining.
questions.explanation: If you must back up, it is safest to back toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This way, as the driver, you will have the best possible view of your path of travel.

questions.question: Regrooved tires are:
questions.answerA: Allowed only on the front of a bus.
questions.answerB: Allowed only on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerC: Not allowed anywhere on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front of a bus.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: If you are disqualified from driving:
questions.answerA: Your employer will be notified by the state.
questions.answerB: You must notify your employer within two business days.
questions.answerC: You must notify your employer within a month.
questions.explanation: You must notify your employer within two business days if your license is suspended, revoked, or canceled, or if you are otherwise disqualified from driving.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle, you should not:
questions.answerA: Park in an area away from buildings, trees, brush, and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Notify emergency services of your problem and your location.
questions.explanation: In the event of a vehicle fire, you should leave the road and stop in an open area. Do not pull into a service station as fuels at the service station could catch fire. Report the fire and your location to emergency services.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day because hazards become more difficult to see in the dark.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: Talking on a cell phone while driving removes about ____ of a person's focus from the task of driving.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is always dangerous. Talking on a cell phone takes away about 39 percent of a person's mental energy that would otherwise be devoted to driving.

questions.question: What must be on all air tanks with air-braked vehicles?
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have a check valve located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. The valve allows air to flow in only one direction and helps keep air from leaving the air compressor if the compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: When changing lanes, turn signals:
questions.answerB: Should only be used if a vehicle is close to you.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions before turning or changing lanes. Do not assume that other drivers will move out of your way simply because you are signaling to turn.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: During an inspection, slack adjusters on S-cam brakes should not move more than:
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for the brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.explanation: The air storage tanks in an air brake system store compressed air to be used for braking. They hold enough air for the brakes to still be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: If a vehicle is carrying hazardous cargo, placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: Only on the front of the vehicle.
questions.answerB: On the front, rear, and sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Only on the driver’s side of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the front, the rear, and both sides of a vehicle carrying hazardous cargo. They must be readable from any direction.

questions.question: Before attempting to put out an engine fire:
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The accelerator should be depressed to use up the remaining fuel.
questions.explanation: If you experience an engine fire, you should turn off the engine as soon as safely possible. Avoid opening the vehicle's hood when extinguishing the fire.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: How much distance will an air brake-equipped vehicle need to come to a complete stop if it is traveling at 55 mph under ideal driving conditions?
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: An emergency brake must be controlled by:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. Because air pressure can eventually leak away, emergency and parking brakes should be held on by mechanical force.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Every vehicle registered in California must have at least:
questions.explanation: In California, every registered motor vehicle must have at least two mirrors, including one that is attached to the lefthand side of the vehicle and located to give a clear view of the roadway to the rear for a distance of at least 200 feet.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hydraulic brake failure?
questions.explanation: Most cases of hydraulic brake failure come from one of two causes. The brakes may fail due to a loss of hydraulic pressure or due to overuse on long hills, causing the brakes to fade.

questions.question: You may not consume alcohol within ____ of going on duty.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicle drivers are prohibited from consuming any intoxicating beverage, regardless of its alcohol content, within four hours of going on duty.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced cargo can cause a vehicle to be difficult to handle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: Do not operate a vehicle if any brake drums have cracks that are larger than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: The radiator cap:
questions.answerA: Should not be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerB: Can be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerC: Should be cool to the touch under normal driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized cooling system until it has cooled. Opening the cap while the system is too hot could release steam and boiling water that could severely burn you. If the radiator cap is cool to the touch, the system is likely cool enough for you to open the cap.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: When should a driver sign a vehicle inspection report?
questions.explanation: You must sign a vehicle inspection report only if defects were noted and either certified to have been repaired or certified as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.answerC: Increases a driver’s ability to steer.
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced loads can lead to unsafe handling. It is important to properly distribute the weight of cargo when loading a vehicle.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: The ____ tells a driver how much pressure is in the air tanks.
questions.explanation: A vehicle that is equipped with air brakes must also be equipped with a supply pressure gauge. This gauge tells the driver how much air pressure is in each of the vehicle's air tanks.

questions.question: Containerized loads are used:
questions.answerA: When the cargo is too large to fit on a truck.
questions.answerB: When the cargo has been or will be transported by a train.
questions.answerC: When the cargo is a liquid.
questions.explanation: Containerized loads are generally used when freight is carried partway by rail or ship. Sealed materials cannot be inspected, but a driver should ensure that the containers do not exceed safe and legal weight limits.

questions.question: If being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Increase the amount of space between your vehicle and the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated, you should increase the distance between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead of you. This reduces the need for you to make sudden changes in speed or direction while making it easier for the tailgater to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Violation points for major violations are retained on a driving record for:
questions.explanation: Points for major violations that occur while driving a commercial motor vehicle, or while you are a CDL holder, will be retained on your record for 55 years.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: While operating on a downgrade, you should brake until you reach a speed that is:
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: If unable to tell if the road is becoming icy and slippery, a driver:
questions.answerB: May open their window and feel the front of the side mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Should look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy but you are not certain, you can open your window and feel the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, a look is when:
questions.answerA: A driver checks the gauges on their instrument panel.
questions.answerB: A driver checks their blind spots.
questions.answerC: A driver walks to the back of their vehicle to check its position.
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake pedal when the spring brakes are on. This could damage the brakes by subjecting them to the combined forces of springs and air pressure.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: Talking on a cell phone while driving removes about ____ of a person's focus from the task of driving.
questions.explanation: Distracted driving is always dangerous. Talking on a cell phone takes away about 39 percent of a person's mental energy that would otherwise be devoted to driving.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Driving with a cargo of hanging meat in a trailer:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals are attracted to the smell of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is challenging because the load has a high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: You should maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle when you are traveling more slowly than 40 mph.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: How can you check for a leak in hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times, then hold down the pedal for five seconds. If the pedal moves, there may be a problem.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake pedal returns to its normal position, there may be a problem.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal down as far as possible and release. If the brake squeaks, there may be a problem.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a tire that is not in the front of a commercial motor vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: Which of the following vehicles is not exempted in requiring the driver to hold a CDL?
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a CDL is not required to operate military vehicles, authorized emergency vehicles, farm equipment, or recreational vehicles. It is also not required for operating a straight truck that contains only your personal property that you are not selling.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should begin by:
questions.answerA: Turning the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turning the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: If your license to operate a personal vehicle is revoked or suspended:
questions.answerA: You can get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerB: You cannot get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerC: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.explanation: If your license to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended, you may not obtain a hardship license to operate a CMV.

questions.question: The maximum height of a load is:
questions.explanation: In California, the maximum height for a vehicle and/or load is 14 feet, as measured from the road surface. Farm equipment which is incidentally driven across highways may exceed this maximum. Double-deck busses may measure 14 feet, 3 inches from the road surface.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. Air brakes may cease to work effectively if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: When drivers turn, they usually:
questions.answerA: Look in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Look in the direction opposite the turn.
questions.explanation: When turning, drivers usually look in the direction of their turn. If a driver fails to signal before a turn or lane change, their body movements may still provide a clue that they are planning to turn.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: You may not consume alcohol within ____ of going on duty.
questions.explanation: Commercial vehicle drivers are prohibited from consuming any intoxicating beverage, regardless of its alcohol content, within four hours of going on duty.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a tire that is not in the front of a commercial motor vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: Why do large vehicles use air brakes?
questions.answerA: Other brake systems squeak too loudly.
questions.answerB: Air brakes are very effective systems.
questions.answerC: Other braking systems are hard to come by.
questions.explanation: If used and maintained properly, air brakes are a safe and effective way to stop large, heavy vehicles.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should begin by:
questions.answerA: Turning the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turning the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: While driving downhill, you should brake until you reach a speed that is ____ below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are far off course.
questions.answerC: You should frequently pull forward to reposition the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When backing, you should pull forward to reposition your vehicle whenever needed. Drift should be corrected immediately by turning the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: When backing up, follow a turning trailer by:
questions.answerA: Changing nothing. The vehicle will naturally follow the trailer.
questions.answerB: Changing the direction of the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Turning the steering wheel even harder in the direction that it is already turning.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: When driving in winter, which of the following should receive extra attention in a pre-trip inspection?
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection during the winter, you should pay extra attention to the coolant level and amount of antifreeze; the defrosting and heating equipment; the wiper blades and windshield washer; the tires and tire chains; the lights and reflectors; the windows and mirrors; the hand holds, steps, and deck plates; the radiator shuttles and winterfront; and exhaust system.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerC: Brake harder than you would with a different braking system.
questions.explanation: When braking a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should not brake any differently than you would if driving a vehicle with a different braking system.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: A pre-trip inspection should include:
questions.answerA: A check of the engine oil level.
questions.explanation: When examining the engine compartment during a pre-trip inspection, you should check the engine oil level, the radiator coolant level, and the condition of the hoses.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.explanation: Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage, so be sure to accelerate smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated while driving a large vehicle, do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you find yourself being tailgated by another driver, you should increase your following distance and avoid making quick moves. Increasing your speed may only result in the other driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed. Do not turn on your taillights or flash your brake lights at the other driver.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop every ____ to take a break to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should stop to take a break at least once for every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections are:
questions.answerB: Needed only for trips longer than 100 miles in length.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before every trip, regardless of length.

questions.question: Which of the following is the best advice for driving in fog?
questions.answerA: Try not to drive in fog.
questions.explanation: Driving in fog is always dangerous and should be avoided entirely if at all possible. If you must drive in fog, be sure to turn on your low beam headlights and fog lights, even during the daytime.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the dates of a trip and the total distance traveled by the vehicle.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: A poor balance of weight in a trailer:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced weight in a trailer can make handling unsafe. For example, either too little or too much weight on the front axle can make a vehicle difficult to steer. Weight should be distributed evenly from front to back and from side to side. It should be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: What is a tire load?
questions.answerA: The minimum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.answerB: The maximum safe weight a tire can carry
questions.explanation: Tire load is defined as the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a specified pressure.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerC: Set the control to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Some older vehicles have front brake limiting valves with "normal" and "slippery" settings. Setting a brake limiting valve to "slippery" reduces the vehicle's stopping power, so a driver should make sure the valve is in its "normal" position. Front wheel braking has proven to be effective in all driving conditions.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When driving on a wet road, you should reduce your speed by:
questions.explanation: Reduce your speed when traveling on surfaces that provide reduced traction. Reduce your speed by about one-third when driving on a wet road.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: When leaving a vehicle unattended, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Only set the parking brake if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual air brakes, a leak in one system ____ the second system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: When adjusting your mirrors before a trip:
questions.answerA: No part of your vehicle should be visible in any mirror.
questions.answerB: Part of your vehicle should be visible in the mirrors.
questions.answerC: More than half of each mirror should show the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When properly adjusted, your mirrors should each display some part of your vehicle. Being able to see your own vehicle in your mirrors will give you a point of reference when judging the positions of other objects.

questions.question: Drivers trapped behind a slow-moving vehicle often:
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle plenty of space.
questions.answerC: Are happy with the speed of travel.
questions.explanation: It is common for drivers to tailgate slow-moving vehicles that cannot keep up with the speed of surrounding traffic. If you are being tailgated, allow the other driver to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: Texting while driving is especially dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is both a mental and physical distraction.
questions.answerB: A message may be upsetting to the driver.
questions.answerC: People like to read and may become too engaged in their phones.
questions.explanation: Texting while driving is particularly dangerous because it is both a mental and physical distraction to the driver. In addition to diverting a driver's mental attention away from the road, texting requires a person to remove at least one hand from the vehicle's controls.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When leaving a vehicle unattended, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Only set the parking brake if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: How should you brake if your vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.answerA: Brake normally, as you will still have functioning brakes.
questions.answerC: Press the brake pedal down as hard as you can.
questions.explanation: Without a working Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), your vehicle will still have normal brake function. Continue to drive and brake as you normally would and have your ABS serviced as soon as possible.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: When checking the engine compartment during the vehicle inspection test, you will need to check the engine oil level.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Should be expected to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Could contain a heavy object that could damage vehicles.
questions.explanation: Almost any foreign object on the road poses some potential danger. For example, even something as seemingly harmless as a cardboard box could contain a hard or heavy object that could damage your vehicle.

questions.question: When inspecting the windshield before a trip, a person should do all the following, except:
questions.answerA: Remove and sharpen the wiper blades.
questions.answerB: Check the windshield wipers for proper spring tension.
questions.answerC: Check the wiper blades for damage.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your windshield, you should look for cracks or other problems that could interfere with your ability to clearly see the road. The windshield wiper arms should be checked for proper spring tension. The wiper blades should be checked for damage, stiff rubber, and improper securement.

questions.question: When inspecting your tires, you do not want to find:
questions.answerA: Tire tread that is 4/32 of an inch deep.
questions.explanation: There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on front tires and 2/32 of an inch on other tires. Valve stems should not be cut or cracked. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: If you are disqualified from driving:
questions.answerA: Your employer will be notified by the state.
questions.answerB: You must notify your employer within two business days.
questions.answerC: You must notify your employer within a month.
questions.explanation: You must notify your employer within two business days if your license is suspended, revoked, or canceled, or if you are otherwise disqualified from driving.

questions.question: A ____ allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes.
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: During the driving test, when asked to make a lane change:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned with other motorists.
questions.answerB: You should use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: You should make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a lane change during the on-road driving test, you should make the proper traffic checks, use your turn signal, and smoothly change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: While driving, gauges are:
questions.answerC: To be monitored for potential signs of trouble.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should watch your vehicle's gauges for signs of trouble. Be sure to inspect your gauges before beginning a trip to ensure that they are in proper working order.

questions.question: Who is responsible for cargo that has been loaded onto a truck?
questions.answerA: The person who loaded the truck
questions.explanation: Even if they did not load or secure the cargo themselves, the driver of a vehicle is responsible for inspecting the cargo and ensuring that it is properly secured.

questions.question: A jogger wearing a stereo headset:
questions.answerA: Is probably aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can hear the sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may be unable to hear your vehicle approaching and may do dangerous things because they do not know you are there.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: When transporting a load, the cargo should be inspected:
questions.answerA: Only at the beginning of a drive.
questions.answerB: Only after driving a long distance.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: Air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Are not allowed on a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Hold compressed air for the brakes.
questions.answerC: Should be drained of excess air after every trip.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks hold compressed air to be used by the brakes. The number and size of air tanks varies among vehicles.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle with air brakes is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a triple combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 5 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, stopping distance:
questions.answerA: Is longer than on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerB: Is not as long as on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerC: Is about the same as on a regular driving surface.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's regular stopping distance increases on slippery surfaces because there is less available traction.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: If you are feeling tired and yawning a lot while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel tired while driving, you should stop to get some sleep. Trying to push on to reach your destination while tired is dangerous. You should not rely on caffeine to keep you awake.

questions.question: A modulating control valve can control the:
questions.explanation: A modulating control valve allows a driver to gradually apply spring brakes. In equipped vehicles, the valve is controlled by a lever located on the dashboard.

questions.question: When in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerA: Slower than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerB: The same speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: Faster than the speed being driven by surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to travel at the same speed as other vehicles. If two vehicles continue to drive in the same direction at the same speed, they cannot hit each other.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: Driving with a cargo of hanging meat in a trailer:
questions.answerA: Is discouraged during the summer months.
questions.answerB: Can be problematic because animals are attracted to the smell of the meat.
questions.answerC: Is challenging because the load has a high center of gravity.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Cargo should be covered:
questions.answerC: To make it more difficult to steal.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
