questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: The ____ are activated by an electric switch that is triggered by the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: An application pressure gauge shows:
questions.answerA: How much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: How much air pressure is available.
questions.answerC: How much air pressure is required to stop a vehicle.
questions.explanation: If a vehicle is equipped, an application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. This gauge can help a driver identify if their brakes are beginning to fade.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Tightens the brake drum onto the axle.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake lining against the wheel.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi, the air compressor governor will:
questions.answerA: Stop the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerC: Begin pumping air into the tanks.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level around 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have ____ malfunction lamps to indicate when the ABS is not working.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with ABS have yellow malfunction lamps to alert drivers when the braking systems are not working. Be sure you know where the malfunction lamp on your vehicle is before beginning a trip.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS):
questions.answerA: Reduce a vehicle's normal braking capacity.
questions.answerB: Are in addition to other braking systems and do not reduce a vehicle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Are not effective on larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: If equipped, ABS is in addition to a vehicle's normal braking system and does not increase or decrease the braking power of any other system. ABS only activates when a vehicle's wheels are about to lock.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: While operating on a downgrade, you should brake until you reach a speed that is:
questions.explanation: While driving downhill, you should hold down the brake pedal until your vehicle reaches a speed 5 mph below your safe speed, then release the brake pedal. Repeat this process.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: To inspect slack adjusters on S-cam brakes, you need to:
questions.answerA: Park on a hill and test the brakes.
questions.answerB: Put on gloves and push in the slack adjusters.
questions.answerC: Chock the wheels and disengage the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: When an S-cam turns inside a brake drum, the S-cam:
questions.answerA: Presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Presses the brake shoes against the brake linings.
questions.answerC: Presses the brake linings against the wheel axles.
questions.explanation: When a brake pedal is pressed and the S-cam is turned, the S-cam presses the brake shoes against the inside of the brake drum. This causes friction and will cause the vehicle to slow.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: Why should you regularly drain the air tanks?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water and the water collects in the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in pressure
questions.explanation: Compressed air usually contains a certain amount of moisture and compressor oil, which can build up in the air storage tanks and damage the brake system. The tanks should be drained to clean out these accumulations. On a tank with a manual drain valve, draining should be performed at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: On flat surfaces, wheel chocks:
questions.answerA: Can be used to prevent a parked vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Make it easier for a parked vehicle to roll.
questions.answerC: Should only be used on the front driver's side tire.
questions.explanation: In situations where a driver cannot use a parking brake, wheel chocks can be used to hold a parked vehicle in place on a level surface.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: The air compressor is connected to the:
questions.explanation: The air compressor of an air brake system is connected to the engine through gears or a v-belt. The compressor may be air-cooled or cooled by the engine cooling system.

questions.question: A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause:
questions.answerB: The tractor protection valve to open.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second trailer, the trailer height should be ____ the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: In a sudden turn, the ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: After completing a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that the:
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: All trailers made after ____ must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).
questions.explanation: All trailers and converter dollies manufactured on or after March 1, 1998 must have Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: An air supply control lever should be in its "normal" position when you are:
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "normal" position, it is properly set for you to pull a trailer.

questions.question: How much space should be between the upper and lower fifth wheel?
questions.answerB: A maximum of two inches of space
questions.explanation: Before a trip, be sure to inspect all couplings. There should be no space between the upper and lower fifth wheel.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Which of the following will not help prevent a rig from rolling over?
questions.answerA: Keeping the cargo as close to the ground as possible
questions.answerC: Driving on the shoulder of a road
questions.explanation: To help prevent a rig from rolling over, you should keep the weight of the cargo as close to the ground as possible when loading. You should also drive slowly around turns.

questions.question: Push in the trailer air supply control to:
questions.explanation: Push in the trailer air supply control to supply the trailer with air. Pull out the trailer air supply control to turn off the air supply and activate the emergency brakes.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: During a trip, the ____ should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that it is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: Operating combination vehicles usually requires ­­­­­____ operating single vehicles.
questions.answerB: About the same level of skill as
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles are usually heavier and longer than single combination vehicles. Operating a combination vehicle requires a higher level of driving skill than operating a single commercial vehicle.

questions.question: To find out if a vehicle that was built before 1998 has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can:
questions.answerA: Pump the air brakes to activate the ABS.
questions.answerB: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Check for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you are operating a vehicle built before 1998 and are unsure if the trailer has an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you can check under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: The emergency air line supplies air to the:
questions.explanation: The emergency air line (also known as the supply line) has two functions. The first is to supply air to the trailer air tanks, and the second is to control the emergency brakes on combination vehicles.

questions.question: The ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over if a driver takes a turn too quickly.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: If you must cross traffic while driving a combination vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough for your vehicle to safely cross.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enonugh gap in traffic to safely do so.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should not be used while you are driving because:
questions.answerA: It will disconnect from the vehicle.
questions.answerB: You will stop the vehicle too quickly.
questions.explanation: Never use the trailer hand valve while operating your vehicle. Using the trailer hand valve while driving can cause your trailer to skid.

questions.question: Keeping cargo centered on a rig can:
questions.explanation: A rollover is more likely if cargo is unevenly loaded in a rig. To help prevent a dangerous rollover, it is important to keep a load as centered on the rig as possible.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: If an air supply control is in its "emergency" position:
questions.answerB: The trailer emergency brakes will be applied.
questions.answerC: The air supply to the trailer will increase.
questions.explanation: Tractor protection controls in older vehicles may be operated by levers instead of knobs. If an air supply control is set in its "emergency" position, the air supply will be stopped and the trailer emergency brakes will be applied.

questions.question: Avoid needing to make sudden lane changes by:
questions.answerA: Using your horn to encourage other drivers to move out of your lane.
questions.answerB: Only driving slower than the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: Watching the road ahead while driving.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous when driving a combination vehicle. Avoid the need to make a sudden lane change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: When backing up while coupling a trailer, the tractor should be positioned:
questions.answerA: Directly in front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When backing up to couple a trailer, you should position the tractor directly in front of the trailer. Trying to couple while backing at an angle could cause the trailer to move and the landing gear to break.

questions.question: In a sudden turn, the ____ trailer is the most likely to turn over.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, be sure to steer gently and smoothly. Making a quick turn while pulling trailers is dangerous and can increase the risk of the last trailer rolling over.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when air pressure drops to a level between:
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Look into the back of the fifth wheel:
questions.answerB: If your vehicle begins to skid.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: Before beginning a trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the service line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves and listening for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When uncoupling a trailer, landing gear should be:
questions.explanation: Landing gear, or trailer supports, should always be completely raised before a vehicle is driven. When uncoupling, landing gear should be lowered to make firm contact with the ground. If a trailer is loaded when it is being uncoupled, you should lower the landing gear and turn the crank a few additional times to remove some weight from the trailer.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance can present challenges when driving over:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerC: You take a turn too fast.
questions.explanation: Rollovers are caused by operators turning too fast. To avoid rolling over, drive slowly on entrance ramps, on exit ramps, and around corners. Avoid making quick lane changes when towing trailers.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerA: Push the brake pedal harder than usual.
questions.answerB: Push the brake pedal as you normally would.
questions.answerC: Push the brake pedal more lightly than usual.
questions.explanation: When operating a vehicle with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should apply your brakes in the same manner as you would if operating a vehicle without ABS.
